CommentCitings.Title: How to Protect Yourself and Others
If You Get a Positive Test Result
If You Get a Negative Test Result
Who's at Risk for Severe Illness?
If You Are Exposed to COVID-19
Call 9-1-1 or Go to the Hospital
Treatment for Mild to Moderate Illness

Comments.Name: If you have symptoms consistent with COVID-19, you should isolate and get tested. This is true even if you have been vaccinated for COVID-19. The risk is low for vaccinated people and people who have had COVID-19 before, but it is possible for them to be infected.

Once you have been infected with COVID-19, you develop antibodies to fight the infection, even if you didn't get sick. Usually, antibodies protect you from getting the same infection again. But with COVID-19, it is not yet clear who is protected, how much antibody is needed to prevent another infection, and how long that protection lasts. For now, experts say to it is best to protect yourself in case reinfection is possible.

Isolation keeps people with a contagious disease separate from people who aren't sick. If you have symptoms of COVID-19 or test positive for COVID-19, this means staying inside your house, not going to work or school, or public places such as grocery stores, shopping malls, movie theaters, restaurants, and libraries.

When quarantining at home, stay at least 6 feet away from other people. Limit yourself to one room and have others stay out. Your bed partner should sleep in a different room. Use a separate bathroom, if available.
--- overweight or obesity (body mass index 25 or higher)

Although rare, Guillain Barre syndrome has been reported within 2 weeks of getting the J&J vaccine. Guillain Barre is a nerve condition that can cause paralysis, although it is usually temporary. The risk is estimated less than 17 instances of GBS in a million doses given. The CDC is monitoring reports of heart inflammation after getting the COVID-19 vaccine. Most of the cases of heart inflammation were among men under age 30, mostly after the Moderna or Pfizer vaccines.

Although the risk is small, men 50 years of age or older are at a slightly increased risk of a neurological condition called Guillain Barre syndrome (GBS) after receiving the Johnson and Johnson COVID-19 vaccine. Based on available data, the risk is less than 17 instances of GBS in a million doses given. Symptoms developed within 2 weeks of getting the vaccine.
--- new persistent chest pain or pressure
--- new confusion or inability to arouse
--- bluish lips or face
--- extreme dizziness or lightheadedness

Even if you are traveling to an area where infection rates are low, some activities can still put you at risk. When you gather with others who have also traveled from a distance, the risk is higher. For this reason, weddings, funerals, large reunions, concerts, sporting events, and rallies have a higher potential of spreading COVID-19. Whenever you are in a crowd, as might occur in a restaurant, bar, cruise ship, or movie theatre, your risk also goes up.

Recommendations for when to get tested for COVID-19 continue to change as the epidemic continues and doctors learn more about the disease. Testing is used to diagnose illness and to contain the spread of infection. If you have symptoms of COVID-19 follow your doctor's advice. If you think that you may be infected, even if you don't have symptoms, you may need testing. Follow guidance from your state and local health departments for the most up-to-date testing recommendations.
--- Had close contact with someone diagnosed with COVID-19 (within 6 feet)

--- Have symptoms: fever, chills, cough, shortness of breath, fatigue, muscle or body aches, headache, loss of taste or smell, sore throat, runny nose, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea, new onset of chest pain, confusion, severe sleepiness, or bluish lips

A small number of young men have developed heart inflammation after receiving the COVID-19 vaccine, mostly the mRNA Moderna or Pfizer vaccines. Scientists at the CDC and the FDA are investigating these reports to see if the heart problem was caused by the vaccine.

If you are awaiting COVID-19 test results, you may need to stay home and avoid people, depending on the reason for your test. People who are vaccinated and boosted against COVID-19 do not need to quarantine after being exposed to COVID-19. If you are testing because you were exposed and are unvaccinated or you have symptoms, stay home until your testing confirms that you do not have COVID-19.
If you had a positive test in the past few weeks, you must stay home and isolate. You may end isolation when you meet the CDC criteria or other guidance from your local health department.

People who are fully vaccinated and boosted (f necessary) or have tested positive for COVID-19 in the past 90 days do not have to quarantine after an exposure to someone with COVID-19 as long as they have fully recovered and remain without symptoms after the exposure. Anyone who has had close contact to a person with COVID-19, however, should wear a tight-fitting mask around others for at least 10 days, and monitor for symptoms.

If you are at high risk for complications of COVID-19 you should be vaccinated as soon as possible. However, people whose immune system is weakened by disease or medications may not mount a strong response to vaccines. A booster dose may be needed. If you are at risk and then exposed to COVID-19, you may benefit from taking preventive treatment, even if you test negative for the infection. Talk to your doctor to find out if this prevention treatment is right for you.

Check for travel advisories on the CDC website before traveling within the US or abroad. People may be denied entry without proof of vaccination, proof of a recently resolved infection, or proof of a recent negative COVID-19 test. All air passengers traveling to the US must show proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 1 day before travel. Others may be denied entry from areas where transmission is high.

Children who have had close contact with a person known to have COVID-19 should be tested 5 to 7 days after the last contact with that person. This is true even if your child has been vaccinated and even if they have had no symptoms. Depending on local guidelines, your child may need to quarantine after contact, if they have not been vaccinated.

COVID-19 self-tests can also be used to reduce the spread of the virus. If you are planning to attend an indoor gathering of people outside of your household, consider doing a self-test beforehand. If the test is positive, avoid the gathering so you do not spread COVID-19 to others. If the first test is negative, you can repeat the test every 24 hours during the time you are gathered with others to increase your confidence that you are not infected with COVID-19.

If you have had close contact with a person who has COVID-19, you may need to quarantine. This means staying home unless you were recently vaccinated. Ideally, everyone should get tested 5 to 7 days after the last contact with that person. This is true even if you are vaccinated and have had no symptoms.

The best choice of test varies depending on the reason you are testing, the availability of different testing strategies in your community, and your level of risk. Talk to your doctor or local health department before you get tested to find the test that is right for you.
--- you wear a tight-fitting mask around others for at least 5 more days, after you leave isolation.

People who tested positive for COVID-19 in the past 3 months do not need to get tested again after exposure. Positive viral tests may remain positive long after an infection has resolved and long after the person is no longer contagious, so it is difficult to know how to interpret their test results.

Some people may need to get a test at or near the end of their 5-day isolation. This is required by some local health authorities and employers. It is best to use an antigen test in this case, and not a NAAT or PCR test. If the antigen test is negative, test at least one more time, 24 to 48 hours later. This lowers the chances that the negative test is a false negative. Do not end isolation if either antigen test is positive.

Booster shots are recommended for all adults and some children because protection from the vaccine fades over time. A booster shot is given months after the first shot or series of shots. Talk to your doctor or health department to find a vaccination clinic near you.

When isolating at home, stay at least 6 feet away from other people. Limit yourself to one room and have others stay out. Your bed partner should sleep in a different room. Use a separate bathroom, if available.

According to experts, risk is likely more related to your RealAge than to your absolute calendar age, but further research needs to be done. Your RealAge is how old your body thinks you are based on your health and health habits, good and bad. It's based on your lifestyle, genetics, and medical history.
You may need a test if you:

Quarantine after close contact is not needed if you are fully vaccinated, as long as you do not develop COVID-19 symptoms. Fully vaccinated people should get tested 5 to 7 days after exposure, even if they don't have symptoms. They should wear a mask indoors in public for 10 days following exposure. People who had a confirmed COVID-19 infection in the previous 3 months also don't need to quarantine after exposure, as long as they have no symptoms.

Infection with coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) may cause no symptoms, mild illness, serious illness, or death. Some people are at more risk than others of becoming seriously ill with COVID-19. They may develop pneumonia, septic shock, respiratory failure, multiorgan failure, and other complications. A portion of people who are infected become sick enough to need intensive care.

If you are an older adult you are more likely than younger adults to develop serious illness, need hospitalization, or require a ventilator to help you breathe. The risk gets progressively higher as you get older. So people in their 50's are at greater risk than people in their 40's, but at lower risk than people in their 60's. People over 85 are at highest risk. Younger people can still get very sick, just not as often.

If you have a preexisting health condition, regardless of your age, you may be more likely to have serious complications from COVID-19. Smoking raises your risk for many of these diseases. It may also increase your risk of problems with COVID-19. Conditions that are known to increase your risk include:
--- serious heart disease, such as coronary artery disease, heart failure, cardiomyopathy, or congenital heart disease
--- high blood pressure
--- chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic bronchitis, or emphysema
--- diabetes type 1 or 2
--- chronic kidney disease
--- blood disorders, such as sickle cell disease
--- weakened immune system (had an organ, blood marrow, or stem cell transplant, or take medicines that lower your immunity)
--- pregnancy
--- nervous system disease, such as dementia
--- Attended a public or private gathering of more than 10 people where not everyone wore a mask all the time or people were not physically distant enough (6 feet minimum between people)

Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) is a disease that mainly affects the lungs and breathing. You usually get it from close contact (within 6 feet or less) with an infected person, even if they have no symptoms. The virus is in the respiratory droplets of an infected person's saliva. It can spread during coughing, sneezing, singing, or just talking. Less often, the virus particles can linger in the air and spread to people who are further away or people who enter the space later.

A small portion of people with COVID-19 develop severe complications including heart or kidney failure. Some people may become prone to clotting which can lead to stroke or heart attack. Care in the hospital is directed to finding and treating any of these complications. Treatment decisions are made based on your condition and your risk for severe complications. This risk increases as you age, if you have a history of smoking, and if you have underlying medical conditions.

Symptoms can begin from 2 to 14 days after exposure. Some people who have COVID-19 have few or no symptoms. Most people have mild illness. Others can become very sick. It can also result in pneumonia, multiorgan failure, or death. Some people are more likely than others to have serious disease. They are people over 60 and people who have certain preexisting conditions, including high blood pressure, heart disease, diabetes, and COPD.

The most common early symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, cough, fatigue, shortness of breath, chills, muscle pain, headache, sore throat, and loss of smell or taste. People may have a runny or stuffy nose and general aches. Although less common, some people have digestive problems like abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting as their first symptoms. Other less common symptoms are conjunctivitis (pink eye) and skin rashes.

COVID-19 is infecting people throughout the US and the world. People who are not vaccinated are at higher risk than others of becoming infected. Anywhere a lot of people are in close contact increases the risk of the virus being shared. Certain areas have high rates of infection. Anyone living or traveling in those areas or in close contact with someone who was recently in one of those areas is also at higher risk, especially if they are not vaccinated.

A vaccine against COVID-19 has been approved for emergency use in adults and children aged 5 years and older. The vaccine is very effective in preventing serious infection, including MIS-C. Boosters may be recommended for some children because protection wanes over time. Masks continue to be very effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19.

A viral test for COVID-19 is widely available in the US. With one type of test, your doctor will swab your nose or throat and send the sample to a lab. This type of test may take days to complete. A rapid test is also approved by the FDA. This test provides results within hours. A COVID-19 self-test for use at home or anywhere has also been approved by the FDA. It is becoming increasingly available.

There is no proven cure for COVID-19 at present. Treatment focuses on relieving symptoms, preventing complications, and shortening time to recovery. Most people who get sick from COVID-19 get better on their own. Some people who get very sick and have problems breathing may need hospitalization. Steroid therapy and antiviral treatment have been shown to lower the risk of death and shorten the length of illness in some people who are hospitalized with COVID-19.

If you are diagnosed with COVID-19, even if you are not ill or your symptoms are mild, you should stay home. If you have a medical condition that increases the risk of serious COVID-19 infection, your doctor may suggest antiviral or monoclonal antibody treatment. These treatments can lower your risk of serious disease. You should also stay away from other people as much as possible while you are sick.
This is a rapidly changing situation. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has the most up-to-date information on https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/.

Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) is a disease that affects the lungs and breathing. Your child can get it from close contact with an infected person. The virus is in the respiratory droplets from an infected person's coughs or sneezes. Less often, the virus particles can linger in the air and spread to people who are further away or people who enter the space later. So far, it appears that most children are at lower risk of serious illness from COVID-19 compared to adults.

Symptoms of COVID-19 begin from 2 to 14 days after exposure to the virus. Symptoms in children are typically less severe than in adults. Only a small portion of infected children need treatment in the hospital. Many children with COVID-19 have no symptoms at all.

Just over one-half of children with COVID-19 have fever, and just over one-third have a cough. Less commonly, nasal congestion, sore throat, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and shortness of breath can occur. Some children who become ill have signs of pneumonia on a chest x-ray or CT scan, but few develop severe or critical illness.

People of any age who have cancer or chronic kidney or lung disease are at higher risk of getting seriously ill from COVID-19. Other risk factors for serious illness in children are sickle cell disease, congenital heart disease, or other medically complex conditions that normally require breathing support. Just as in adults, children who have diabetes or decreased immunity or are obese may be at increased risk for severe illness with COVID-19.

COVID-19 is infecting people around the world. Certain areas of the country and the world have higher rates of infection, but few are risk-free. Living and traveling in areas where there are a lot of cases increases your risk, especially if you are not vaccinated and if you gather in close contact (less than 6 feet apart) with other people. Being indoors with little or no ventilation, also increases the risk, compared to being outdoors.

The best ways to prevent infection with COVID-19 for children under 5 who are currently too young to receive the vaccine are to wear a mask in public and keep a 6-foot distance from others. Your child should avoid contact with anyone who is sick, if possible. They should avoid touching their eyes, nose, and mouth. Face coverings are not recommended for children under the age of 2.

COVID-19 spreads easily when people are in close contact, so your child should avoid unnecessary large gatherings, especially if a 6-foot distance is not possible. Follow your current state and local guidelines for getting together with others in public places. At school or daycare, indoor masking is recommended for all regardless of vaccination status.

Viral testing for COVID-19 is widely available in the US. With one type of test your doctor will swab your child's nose or throat and send the sample to a lab. These tests may take days to complete. A rapid test is also approved by the FDA. This test provides results within hours. Children who have symptoms of MIS-C may have a negative viral test. In this case, their doctor may use an antibody test for COVID-19 to see if there is evidence of past COVID-19 infection.

If your child is diagnosed with COVID-19, even if they are not ill or their symptoms are mild, they should stay home. If your child has a medical condition that increases the risk of serious COVID-19 infection, your doctor may suggest antiviral or antibody treatment. These treatments can lower the risk of serious disease. Your child should also stay away from other people as much as possible while they are sick.
People with symptoms that are very severe may need treatment in a hospital. If you develop any of these emergency warning signs for coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19), get medical attention immediately:
--- extreme difficulty breathing

COVID-19 is spread from person to person by way of droplets when the infected person coughs, sneezes, sings, or even talks. People who are closest (within 6 feet of an infected person) are at highest risk of getting infected. The virus may also briefly linger in the air after the infected person has left. People who inhale the virus may become infected. This is especially likely in indoor spaces that are not well ventilated.
--- lung diseases, such as asthma, pulmonary fibrosis, cystic fibrosis

All people, especially those who have not been vaccinated should practice basic habits including washing your hands well, regularly cleaning surfaces where germs might be found, keeping a safe distance from anyone who is sneezing or coughing, and staying away from large gatherings and poorly ventilated indoor spaces. Face masks can lower transmission of COVID-19 and are recommended for people who are over 2, especially when other prevention options are not possible.

A small portion of people who have COVID-19 develop more serious illness. They may have extreme difficulty breathing and often need treatment in a hospital, including oxygen support. Some people must be admitted to an intensive care unit.
--- coughing up blood

The CDC revised its isolation guidelines in December 2021. The guidelines do not replace guidance from your local health authority. Check with your local health department for isolation advice that applies to you. According to the newer CDC guidance, it is okay to stop isolation when all of the following are true:
--- your fever has stopped by itself (without fever-reducing medication) for at least 24 hours AND
--- your other symptoms have improved AND
--- at least 5 days have passed since your symptoms started

For women between 18 and 50 years of age, there is an extremely low risk of developing a serious clotting disorder called thrombocytopenia syndrome after taking the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine. The risk is less than 10 in a million doses. For this reason, the CDC now recommends that all adults use either of the mRNA vaccines rather than the Johnson and Johnson vaccine, whenever possible.

Once you are fully vaccinated (2 weeks after the last dose), you may begin to return to life with a significantly smaller infection risk. The risk of COVID-19 infection in vaccinated people is not zero, so masks may still be recommended. This is especially true if you or someone in your home is at increased risk of severe disease.
If you develop symptoms, you must stay in home isolation at least 5 days after your symptoms began, until:
--- at least 5 days have passed since your first positive test result AND
--- you have not developed symptoms AND

If you have had an immediate allergic reaction, even if it was not severe, to a vaccine or other type of injection therapy for another disease, ask your doctor if you should get a COVID-19 vaccine. Your doctor will help you decide if it is safe for you to get vaccinated. If you have a history of allergy to any of the components of the COVID-19 vaccine, you should not receive that specific vaccine. Tell your doctor if you are allergic to polyethylene glycol or polysorbate.

If you have not developed symptoms, you should test no sooner than 5 days after the last contact with the infected person. If you test negative, you may end quarantine but wear a tight-fitting mask around others for 10 days since the last contact. If you test positive you are infected with the virus even if you have not developed symptoms. You must isolate yourself until at least 5 days have passed since your first positive.

You can stop quarantine when 5 days have passed since you had contact with an infected person, as long you do not become ill. Check with your local health department to be certain of local restrictions. During that time, continue to practice social distancing and monitor your health for COVID-19 symptoms. If you develop symptoms, get tested right away and continue to quarantine.

In addition to age and medical conditions, some people and groups of people are also likely to be at increased risk of serious illness with COVID-19. These include people with disabilities, people in prisons, refugees, and people who are black, indigenous, or other people of color who do not have access to healthcare or are more likely to live in crowded circumstances.

If the virus lands on a surface, it can be spread to an uninfected person, but this is less common. The virus must enter the body through the mouth, nose, or eye. The best way to prevent this from happening it to keep surfaces clean, wash your hands often, and avoid touching your face, mouth, eyes, and nose after touching a surface.

You can even catch COVID-19 by being in close contact with someone who is infected but does not show any signs of illness. Some newer variants of COVID-19 are even more contagious than earlier variants. Even people who are vaccinated against COVID-19 can become infected and transmit the infection to others. How often this occurs is not known, but it occurs far less often than among people who are not vaccinated.

As newer more contagious COVID-19 variants become more common in the US, more cases are occurring among children. Because children under the age of 5 are not yet eligible for vaccination, they are more vulnerable to these more contagious variants. Unlike earlier in the pandemic, children represent a larger portion of cases because older people are more likely to be vaccinated. However, it remains true that severe illness among children is uncommon.

Since newer more contagious variants of COVID-19 are increasingly common, even people who are fully vaccinated should be tested if they have been in close contact with an infected person. The recommended timing of the testing and the length of the quarantine needed differs depending on your vaccine status and whether or not you develop symptoms. If you had a confirmed COVID-19 infection within the previous 3 months testing is not needed after COVID-19 exposure.

If you have had close contact (within 6 feet or less) with anyone in the past 10 days, tell them that you have tested positive for COVID-19. If they are not completely vaccinated and boosted, they need to quarantine themselves so they don't expose others. All contacts should monitor for symptoms. If symptoms occur they should be tested right away. If no symptoms occur, contacts should get tested 5 to 7 days after their last exposure, regardless of their vaccine status.

Other effective prevention strategies include keeping distance (at least 6 feet) from others and avoiding crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces. Washing your hands often for 20 seconds with soap and water or hand sanitizer is also recommended.

A small portion of children and young adults may develop Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C). Symptoms are similar to those of Kawasaki disease or toxic shock syndrome. They may include a distinctive raised red rash all over the body and a persistent fever. The child may also have red eyes, a sore throat, swollen glands, vomiting, or abdominal pain. They may seem irritable or confused. A test for COVID-19 may be positive or negative.

Some people have persistent symptoms after their initial infection has improved. Doctors are not sure why this happens to some people after COVID-19 infection and not others, and more study is needed. The most common symptoms that are reported in people with this so-called "long-haul COVID-19" are fatigue, shortness of breath, cough, joint pain, and chest pain. Other people have reported difficulty concentrating, problems with memory, headaches, and depression.
--- Work or live in an area that is requiring regular testing to prevent community spread

During the COVID-19 pandemic travel has been limited for everyone. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) discourages nonessential travel for unvaccinated people until the risk of travel is better understood. You can get infected or spread the virus to others. If you are unvaccinated and must travel, wear masks and socially distance in public, and whenever you are with anyone at high risk of infection.

Some state and local governments have specific restrictions for travelers. All travelers should monitor for symptoms when they return home. Unvaccinated people should get tested for COVID-19 1 to 3 days before travel. They should get tested 3 to 5 days after travel and quarantine for 7 days. Unvaccinated people who do not get tested need to quarantine for 10 days after returning home. Do not travel if you are sick or if you have been around someone with COVID-19.

Fully vaccinated people can travel more safely within the US, but all travelers should continue to follow basic prevention tips. Wash your hands with soap and water or use hand sanitizer after you have been in public places and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing. Regardless of your vaccine status, you can lower your risk by keeping 6 feet away from others you do not know, avoiding crowds, and wearing a face mask in public when traveling.

Traveling by airplane presents additional challenges, especially if you are unvaccinated or you are at higher risk for serious illness with COVID-19. Airports and their security measures may bring you into close contact with others and with frequently touched surfaces. When on the plane, you are often less than 6 feet from other people for the duration of a flight. Check the airline and the airports through which you are traveling to learn about specific guidelines.

If you chose to travel by bus or train, you may also be less than 6 feet from people for a long time in an enclosed space. This increases your risk of COVID-19 if you are unvaccinated. Travel by car may also put you in contact with strangers if you stop along the way to get gas or use public bathrooms. Plan ahead. Bring your own food and water to minimize food stops. Bring a mask for use in public and have hand sanitizer available to use when handwashing is not available.
--- cerebrovascular disease, such as stroke
--- liver disease
--- thalassemia

The best way to stay healthy is to get vaccinated. All of the vaccines approved for use in the US have been shown to be very effective in reducing the risk of severe COVID-19 infection. The vaccine is approved for people aged 5 years and older in the US. An additional primary shot is recommended for people with weakened immune systems. Boosters are available and recommended for anyone 12 years of age or older, depending on when they finished their primary series of shots.
--- HIV or AIDS
--- cancer

The treatment options for mild, moderate, and severe COVID-19 are in development in the US and elsewhere. Clinical trials are being done to determine their effectiveness and safety as doctors learn more about COVID-19. The US National Institute of Health website maintains current information for patients and their doctors regarding recommended safe and effective treatments. It is expected these treatments will change over time.
--- substance use disorder

People with mild symptoms of COVID-19 usually do not need treatment except to minimize the discomfort of their symptoms and lower the likelihood of virus transmission to others. A pulse oximeter can measure your oxygen level easily at home to make sure your level stays at a safe level.

Testing may be done at the doctor's office or a clinic sponsored by your local health department. They will swab your nose or throat and send the sample to a lab. These nucleic acid amplification (NAAT) tests can take days to complete. Rapid tests may also be used in clinics and other settings. These tests may provide results within hours. A rapid self-test for use at home is increasingly available. Self-testing is one way to lower your chance of spreading COVID-19 to others.

Sometimes your doctor will recommend you take an antiviral drug or a monoclonal antibody treatment, even if your symptoms are mild. These medications may be recommended early in the course of COVID-19 infection for people who are at risk of severe illness to prevent serious disease. Monoclonal antibodies are proteins made in a laboratory that behave like antibodies in your immune system.

Treatment for more severe COVID-19 is aimed at keeping oxygen levels at a safe level and treating various complications that occur in some people with COVID-19. Early in COVID-19 infection, the virus is multiplying in the body. Later in the infection, the body sometimes responds to the virus with an exaggerated immune response or severe inflammation. For this reason antiviral treatment is more effective early, while anti-inflammatory treatments are more effective later.

COVID-19 infection can keep your lungs from providing oxygen to your blood and vital organs. Your doctor can provide you with supplemental oxygen through a mask. This is usually done in the hospital. If this is not enough to keep your circulating oxygen at a safe level, you may need to be put on a ventilator. Ventilators actually pump air directly into the lungs when they cannot perform this function themselves. Ventilation care is usually provided in an intensive care unit.

People who are getting supplemental oxygen therapy, with or without a ventilator, benefit from the anti-inflammatory medication dexamethasone. This corticosteroid medication has been shown to shorten the amount of time that oxygen therapy or ventilation is needed. Your doctor may also give you remdesivir, an antiviral medication, if you are on oxygen therapy without ventilation. This medicine has not been shown to be useful once a person is on a ventilator.

If ventilation, dexamethasone, and remdesivir are not enough to improve your condition, and if the lungs are showing evidence of rapid decline, your doctor may give you the medication tocilizumab or other drugs that can dampen inflammation.
If you are hospitalized for COVID-19, your doctor may give you a low dose of an anticoagulation medicine to prevent blood clots.

CAM practices may help relieve some aspects of illness with COVID-19. Some nutrients have shown benefits for other viral respiratory infections. CAM therapies such as meditation, relaxation, acupuncture, and exercise may be helpful in relieving some physical and psychological factors of COVID-19 illness. Eating a healthy diet can improve your immune system function, fight inflammation, and help you lose weight to reduce your risk of serious COVID-19 illness.

Because of the newness of this infection, there is very little evidence to support the use of any specific complementary or alternative (CAM) treatments that can prevent or effectively treat COVID-19. There is much misinformation on the internet and social media promoting cures and preventive therapies for COVID-19. Some can actually be harmful to your health. It is important to check the facts and review the evidence behind these claims to separate the myths from the facts.

While herbal and other complementary medicines might have positive benefits on the immune system or possible antiviral or anti-inflammatory activity, there is not enough evidence to recommend them specifically for COVID-19 treatment. Further study is needed to weigh both the potential benefits and the potential harms.

If your test result is negative, it is possible you were not infected with COVID-19 when the test was done. It may also mean it was early in the infection period (false negative) and a repeat test would have a positive result. Depending on the reason for testing, you may need to continue to stay away from others to prevent spread of COVID-19. Your doctor may recommend a repeat test with a NAAT test, if you used a rapid antigen test first.
If your test comes back positive, you are likely infected with COVID-19. Follow the guidance in this tool as well as that of your doctor and local health officials to care for yourself and others.

Another test can tell if you have had the infection in the past. It is called an antibody or serology test. This is a test that measures the level of antibodies to coronavirus that are circulating in your bloodstream. Antibodies are formed when your immune system fights off an infection. Usually the antibodies can be seen 1 to 3 weeks after you have had symptoms. You may also have a positive antibody test after exposure to the virus, even if you didn't have any symptoms.
--- Are boarding a plane into the US or you just returned from traveling away from home

Antibody testing is not recommended to diagnose a case of COVID-19, except under rare circumstances. Also, doctors don't know yet if having a positive antibody test means you can't be infected again. You are probably protected from the virus at least temporarily. Antibody tests are being used to monitor where COVID-19 infections are occurring in the community.

Antibody tests have false negatives and false positives too. False positives are more likely if the risk of infection with COVID-19 is low. False negatives are more likely if the risk of infection with COVID-19 is high. Regardless of an antibody test result, continue to use precautions to lower the risk of spreading infection.

Although the actual risk is small, women who are pregnant are at increased risk of complications if they get COVID-19 infection. The COVID-19 vaccine is recommended for pregnant and breastfeeding women. It has been shown to lower the woman's risk of serious infection. It may also protect her newborn from COVID-19. Talk to your doctor about getting the vaccine. Together, you can weigh the risks of infection, the amount of transmission in your community, and your personal risk.

Quarantine keeps someone who may have been exposed to an infection away from other people to prevent spread. While you wait for your test results, stay home unless your doctor tells you otherwise or you need emergency help. This means staying inside your house, not going to work or school, or public places such as grocery stores, shopping malls, movie theaters, restaurants, and libraries. Do not leave your house unless you are going to the doctor.

Vaccines against COVID-19 have been approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA). They are very effective in preventing serious infection. Immunity appears to fade over time, so booster shots are needed. Masks are also effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. You may not always need to wear a mask if you are vaccinated, but it can reduce your risk even more.

People with COVID-19 sometimes develop serious complications of the infection. Once you are in the hospital the doctors will monitor your breathing and oxygen levels because pneumonia and respiratory distress can occur. In some cases, you will need oxygen therapy or breathing assistance on a ventilator. Intensive care treatment in an ICU may be necessary. Medications, including the corticosteroid, dexamethasone, antiviral treatments, or antibody treatments may be recommended.
--- Down syndrome
--- essential oils or herbal therapies or tinctures

The CDC recommends COVID-19 vaccination for anyone 5 years of age and older. They also recommend an extra dose of vaccine for people who have a weak immune system. This will give them the highest level of protection from the vaccine.

Getting vaccinated against COVID-19 is the safest way to build up your body's immunity against the infection. It can protect you and those closest to you from getting ill. Getting sick with COVID-19 will provide some protection from future infection, but it also can cause life-threatening illness, persistent fatigue and cognitive impairment, even after the original infection has gone. Vaccination efforts can raise the level of immunity across the country to slow the pandemic.

Benefits: COVID-19 vaccines that are in use in the US are highly effective in preventing COVID-19 infection. In clinical trials, the effectiveness of the vaccines was estimated to be between 90% and 94% in preventing serious illness with COVID-19. Experts continue to collect data on vaccine effectiveness as more and more people are vaccinated to estimate effectiveness in real world settings.

Side Effects: The most common side effects of COVID-19 vaccination are not severe and include redness and soreness at the injection site, swelling in the armpit on the side the shot was given, and mild, flu-like symptoms. These might include fever, fatigue, headache, chills, and muscle or joint pain within 3 days of getting the shot. They are more common after the second dose of the two-dose vaccines. Serious allergic reactions have occurred, but they are rare.

Adverse reactions: As with every vaccine there is a possibility of a severe allergic reaction to the COVID-19 vaccine. This occurs in about 5 out of every million vaccines given. There is a small risk of blood clots after taking the J&J/Janssen COVID-19 vaccine. The risk is less than 10 in a million doses, with women between 18 and 50 years of age at greatest risk. Because of this risk, the CDC advises that adults get an mRNA vaccine, whenever possible.
Talk to your doctor if you have any questions or concerns about the COVID-19 vaccination.

None of the following have yet been proven to prevent people from getting COVID-19 and none of them are cures for the virus. Some of them may help relieve symptoms, but if used improperly some have side effects. They are not currently recommended to protect you from infection with COVID-19 or as treatment if you are diagnosed with it.
--- zinc
--- Vitamin C
--- saline nose rinse
--- traditional Chinese medicine (TCM)
--- garlic or other foods with antimicrobial properties
--- acetic acid
--- colloidal silver
